Fun isnt it! 
had a close look and no clear evidence of 3 layer constructio=
n (sorry) Its bugging me too. Having said that it screams quality (at least=
 to me)and looks absolutely great on a Daido katana for which I am attempti=
ng to put a together a koshirae . I started looking for Owari then this cam=
e up and I was very taken with it. After a lot of looking it still seems to=
 fall between two camps, Owari or early Akasaka.
try not to loose any sleep=
 thinking about it.
regards
paul

Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@...> wro=
te:
Paul,
Thanks for the photo.  By round, I was picturing a rounded maru m=
imi, not a round cross section.  A round cross section is not typical for e=
arly Akasaka guards.  Later when the Akasaka were copying Higo work, they u=
sed their thinner style of round section rim.  I don't think I've seen this=
 kind of rim on an Akasaka piece, but I can't say it's impossible.  They di=
d some unusual things.

I'm not sure about your piece.  The looseness of th=
e sukashi design reminds me of early Akasaka, although the bird at the top =
is pretty thick for them.  The iron surface shows more "modulation" that is=
 typical for Akasaka.  It looks more like something from the Owari region. =
 The seppa dai is not far from Akasaka shape.  The guard reminds me a littl=
e of a third generation piece that I have:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggi=
lbert/akasaka.htm  (second guard down from the top).

Looking inside the su=
kashi openings do you see any signs of three layer construction?

Tough one=
... it's bugging me already.  Some Akasaka style, but a lot that is not.  A=
nd I don't know what the "is not" part is.  Thinking out loud...

Jim



  =
Thanks Jim,
  Yes I did intend to attach a photo, sorry I might get the han=
g of technology in another 30 or 40 years. I have put the image in the albu=
m (I think) under paulb. Please take a look and let me know if its there an=
d what you think.
  many thanks
  paul

  Jim Gilbert <jggilbert@EARTHLINK.=
NET> wrote:
  Paul,
  A thick, round rim is typical for early Akasaka guard=
s.  Later ones tend to be thinner.  The early Akasaka really favored a very=
 "high," rounded rim compared with other groups working at the same time.

=
  Sometimes tekkotsu are seen in early examples.  Senkotsu is more common, =
which is a sort of long linear bone that forms where the inner and outer pl=
ates are joined.  

  I'm not sure if you intended there to be an attached =
photo.  The list doesn't permit attachments, but you can post images in the=
 group photo album at:
  http://groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/

  Log=
 in and click on the "Photos" link at the left.  I can provide detailed ins=
tructions for anyone who would like to learn how to post photos. It's quite=
 easy.

  Jim 



    Dear All,
    I have been discussing the tsuba below =
with a number of friends from both this and another group. The concensus to=
 date is that this is early Akasaka. While I am more than content with that=
 attribution I was wondering how common the thick round mimi was in Aakasak=
a work? Also there are a lot of bones in the mimi. I understand that early =
Akasaka work was influenced by Owari tsuba, is this an example of this? or =
should I be looking in another direction.
    All comments greatly apprecia=
ted.
